elements.content: A new series of coordination polymers, namely, CP2 [{(H2O)­Co1.5(μ-3-bpna)1.5(μ-btc)}·3DMF·3H2O]α, CP3 [{Cd­(μ-3-bpna)­(μ-hbtc)}·CH3OH·2H2O]α, CP4 [{Co­(μ-3-bpna)­(μ-ipa)}·DMF·2H2O]α, CP5 [{Co­(μ-3-bpna)­(μ-1,3-pda)}·DMF]α, CP6 [Cd­(μ-3-bpna)0.5(μ-1,3-pda)]α, CP7 [(H2O)­Co0.5(μ-3-bpna)0.5(μ-1,4-pda)0.5]α, and CP8 [{Zn­(μ-3-bpna)­(μ-oba)}·DMF·2H2O]α, has been synthesized by reacting a hydrogen-bond-functionalized bis-pyridyl ligand, namely, N′,N″-di­(pyridin-3-yl)­naphthalene-2,6-dicarboxamide, with various transition metal salts and different di- or tricarboxylates (as co-ligand) displaying 2D and 3D network topology and having lattice-occluded solvents in the majority of cases. A 1D coordination polymer, namely, CP1 [{Ag0.5(μ-3-bpna)}0.5·0.5BF4·CH3CN]α, has also been isolated by reacting 3-bpna with AgBF4 in the absence of any carboxylate co-ligand. All of the CPs were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Interestingly, two such CPs, namely, CP1 and CP2, produced metallogels, which were characterized by rheology, transmission electron microscopy, and X-ray powder diffraction. The metallogel of CP1 produced Ag nanoparticles within the gel bed upon exposure to light.

elements.content: A rational approach has been adopted to synthesize a new series of coordination polymers derived from 3-bpna under various conditions. Two such coordination polymers (CP1 and CP2) produced metallogels. Ag nanoparticles have also been isolated from one such metallogel.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) are an important class of metal–organic hybrid compounds that are formed spontaneously when a multidentate organic linker(s) (ligand) is allowed to react with an appropriate metal salt(s). The field really took off when Robson et al. reported a CuII diamondoid network derived from three dimensionally linked rod-like segments, namely, 4,4′,4″,4‴- tetracyanotetraphenyl methane. CPs are usually highly crystalline compounds, enabling their detailed structural characterization at the atomic level by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD). Such sub-molecular-level structural information led researchers to design a wide variety of CPs with potential applications in gas storage, anion and cation separation, catalysis, magnetic materials, drug delivery, sensors, optoelectronics, and others.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs) are an important class of metal-organic hybrid compounds that are formed spontaneously when a multidentate organic linker(s) (ligand) is allowed to react with an appropriate metal salt(s). The field really took off when Robson et al. reported a CuII diamondoid network derived from three dimensionally linked rod-like segments, namely, 4,4',4",4‴- tetracyanotetraphenyl methane. CPs are usually highly crystalline compounds, enabling their detailed structural characterization at the atomic level by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD). Such sub-molecular-level structural information led researchers to design a wide variety of CPs with potential applications in gas storage, anion and cation separation, catalysis, magnetic materials, drug delivery, sensors, optoelectronics, and others.

elements.content: As part of our ongoing research program on CPs, we are interested in developing CPs that have intriguing structures and functions, such as in situ anion and cation separation, metallogelation, metal-nanoparticle synthesis and catalysis, and so on. For this purpose, we have been focusing on pyridyl- or carboxylate-based multidentate ligands equipped with a hydrogen-bonding-capable backbone such as an amide or urea functionality. Among the various potential applications that CPs offer, metallogelation is extremely important to study because of its potential applications in catalysis, sensing, photophysics, synthesis of nanomaterials, magnetic materials, and so forth. A gel is a soft material displaying the properties of both a solid and liquid. It is usually formed by the immobilization of a liquid (gelling solvent) within a gel network that is formed either by purely noncovalent interactions (hydrogen bonding, π–π stacking, van der Waals interactions, etc.) or by polymerization via covalent bond formation. When a metal ion is a part of the gel network, the resulting gel is called a metallogel. A supramolecular gel containing a metal nanoparticle is also called a metallogel. Discrete coordination compounds, infinite CP, and crossed-linked CPs all have been shown to be capable of immobilizing (gelling) solvent to produce metallogels.

Among the various potential applications that CPs offer, metallogelation is extremely important to study because of its potential applications in catalysis, sensing, photophysics, synthesis of nanomaterials, magnetic materials, and so forth. A gel is a soft material displaying the properties of both a solid and liquid. It is usually formed by the immobilization of a liquid (gelling solvent) within a gel network that is formed either by purely noncovalent interactions (hydrogen bonding, π-π stacking, van der Waals interactions, etc.) or by polymerization via covalent bond formation. When a metal ion is a part of the gel network, the resulting gel is called a metallogel. A supramolecular gel containing a metal nanoparticle is also called a metallogel. Discrete coordination compounds, infinite CP, and crossed-linked CPs all have been shown to be capable of immobilizing (gelling) solvent to produce metallogels.

elements.content: Designing CPs is a challenging task. There have been several efforts by various groups to meet such a challenge; for example, introducing a long alkyl chain (hydrophobic group) in a coordination complex, installing a well-known aromatic-linker-steroid (ALS) moiety (a well-known gel-forming moiety) on a metallocene, utilizing surface modifications with mixed ligands of different lengths, slowly crystallizing CPs with flexible ligands, exploiting the well-studied supramolecular synthon, and others. In an another approach, we and others have suggested that molecular solids having lattice occluded solvents are good candidates for gelation because of the structural similarity present between the gels and the solvent occluded molecular solids; in both the cases, a large amount of solvents was occluded.
elements.clean_text: Designing CPs is a challenging task. There have been several efforts by various groups to meet such a challenge; for example, introducing a long alkyl chain (hydrophobic group) in a coordination complex, installing a well-known aromatic-linker-steroid (ALS) moiety (a well-known gel-forming moiety) on a metallocene, utilizing surface modifications with mixed ligands of different lengths, slowly crystallizing CPs with flexible ligands, exploiting the well-studied supramolecular synthon, and others. In an another approach, we and others have suggested that molecular solids having lattice occluded solvents are good candidates for gelation because of the structural similarity present between the gels and the solvent occluded molecular solids; in both the cases, a large amount of solvents was occluded.

elements.content: With this background in mind, we set out to synthesize a new series of CPs that is expected to generate lattice occluded solids, which, under suitable conditions, might display metallogelation behavior. For this purpose, we synthesized a hitherto unexplored bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligand, namely, N′,N″-di­(pyridin-3-yl)­naphthalene-2,6-dicarboxamide (hereafter, 3-bpna). We envisaged that the amide moieties and relatively large π-cloud of the central naphthyl ring would be of some help in the self-assembly process of gelation via hydrogen bonding and π–π stacking interactions, respectively. Moreover, the amide functionality is also expected to invite guest molecules as lattice occluded solvents, which, in turn, might contribute to the metallogelation behavior of the resulting CPs. A series of crystalline CPs was indeed isolated when 3-bpna was reacted with various metal salts and different bis- or tris-carboxylate co-ligands ().

elements.content: All chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were carried out using a PerkinElmer 2400 series II CHN analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded using PerkinElmer Spectrum GX. The mass spectra were recorded with a Q-TOF Micro YA 263 mass spectrometer. NMR spectra (1H and 13C) were recorded using a 300 MHz Bruker Avance DPX 200 spectrometer. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were obtained from solid films prepared by drop casting an aqueous suspension of 3-bpna and the CPs on quartz plates using a Nanolog spectrofluorometer from HORIBA Jobin Yvon.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were carried out using a PerkinElmer 2400 series II CHN analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded using PerkinElmer Spectrum GX. The mass spectra were recorded with a Q-TOF Micro YA 263 mass spectrometer. NMR spectra (1H and 13C) were recorded using a 300 MHz Bruker Avance DPX 200 spectrometer. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were obtained from solid films prepared by drop casting an aqueous suspension of 3-bpna and the CPs on quartz plates using a Nanolog spectrofluorometer from HORIBA Jobin Yvon.

elements.content: To a solution of 2,6-napthalenedicarboxylic acid (500 mg, 2.3 mmol) in dry dichloromethane (DCM) were added 2 mL of oxalyl chloride and 4 drops of DMF, and the mixture was stirred with a gut tube for 12 h to yield a yellow suspension that was dried under vacuum. The dried powder was stirred in toluene for 2 h, and the sticky mass of oxalyl chloride was removed by decanting the toluene solution, which was further evaporated to isolate the pure acid chloride as a dried mass (600 mg, 2.37 mmol, yield: 70%).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Ligand 3-bpna 

To a solution of 2,6-napthalenedicarboxylic acid (500 mg, 2.3 mmol) in dry dichloromethane (DCM) were added 2 mL of oxalyl chloride and 4 drops of DMF, and the mixture was stirred with a gut tube for 12 h to yield a yellow suspension that was dried under vacuum. The dried powder was stirred in toluene for 2 h, and the sticky mass of oxalyl chloride was removed by decanting the toluene solution, which was further evaporated to isolate the pure acid chloride as a dried mass (600 mg, 2.37 mmol, yield: 70%).

elements.content: To a solution of the acid chloride (550 mg, 2.1 mmol) and 1 mL of triethylamine in dry DCM was added 3-amino pyridine (395 mg, 4.2 mmol) in dry THF dropwise. The thick white colored precipitate thus formed was stirred with refluxing for 12 h. After filtration, the precipitate was washed with a DCM/THF mixture, air-dried, treated with a 5% NaHCO3 solution, washed with distilled water, dried, and recrystallized from DMSO (yield: 650 mg, 70%). Anal. Calcd for C22H16N4O2 (%): C, 71.73; H, 4.38; N, 15.21. Found: C, 71.42; H, 4.14; N, 15.00. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ = 10.73 (2H, s), 8.99 (2H, s), 8.69 (2H, s), 8.35–8.34 (2H, d, J = 5 Hz), 8.26–8.25 (4H, d, J = 5 Hz), 8.13–8.12 (2H, d, J = 5 Hz), 7.45–7.43 (2H, dd, J = 5, 5 Hz) ppm. ESI-MS: calcd for C22H16N4O 369.18 (M + 1). Found: [M + Na]+ 391.17. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3346, 3265, 3047, 1670, 1596, 1541, 1479, 1413, 1328, 1307, 1234, 1184, 1134, 1105, 1024, 943, 916, 900, 811, 790, 752, 700, 632, 487, 408.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Characterization of CPs

CP1

 CP1 was synthesized by carefully layering a CH3CN solution of AgBF4 (31 mg, 0.16 mmol) onto a DMSO solution of 3-bpna (30 mg, 0.08 mmol) in a thin long glass tube, which was then kept for slow evaporation at room temperature. After 3 weeks, X-ray quality block-shaped white crystals were obtained. Anal. Calcd for C24H19AgBF4N5O2 (%): C, 47.72; H, 3.17; N, 11.59. Found: C, 47.18; H, 3.63; N, 10.79. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3398, 3083, 1672, 1596, 1541, 1481, 1413, 1328, 1307, 1263, 1234, 1188, 1134, 1105, 1070, 1026, 945, 916, 790, 700, 632, 487.

elements.content: CP2 was synthesized under solvothermal conditions from a DMF/methanol/water solution (3:1:1) of a mixture of 3-bpna (30 mg, 0.08 mmol), Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (23.2 mg, 0.08 mmol), and trimesic acid (16.8 mg, 0.08 mmol). The mixture was taken in a 25 mL torsion vial, heated at 75 °C for 60 h, and allowed to cool slowly (5 °C per hour in 12 h). After cooling, block-shaped pink crystals were isolated. Anal. Calcd for C40H43Co2N7O11 (%): C, 52.47; H, 4.73; N, 10.71 Found: C, 51.97; H, 4.54; N, 11.03. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3334, 3056, 1662, 1606, 1541, 1485, 1436, 1384, 1301, 1280, 1240, 1134, 1099, 1051, 929, 819, 800, 729, 700, 659, 640, 630, 594, 584.

CP8

The synthetic procedure was similar to that of CP2 under solvothermal conditions from a DMF/methanol/water solution of a mixture of 3-bpna (30 mg, 0.08 mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (24.6 mg, 0.08 mmol), and oxy-bisbenzoic acid (20.6 mg, 0.08 mmol). After cooling, plate-shaped crystals were isolated. Anal. Calcd for C44H46ZnN4O10 (%): C, 61.72; H, 4.68; N, 9.13. Found: C, 61.01; H, 4.08; N, 8.63. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3276, 3078, 1666, 1595, 1544, 1500, 1421, 1400, 1284, 1232, 1188, 1134, 877, 808, 784, 773, 698, 663, 649, 599.

elements.content: In a typical gelation experiment for CP1, 3-bpna (22 mg, 0.06 mmol) was dissolved in 0.4 mL of hot DMF to obtain a clear solution and mixed with 0.6 mL of an aqueous solution of AgBF4 (11.7 mg, 0.06 mmol) at room temperature so that the metal/ligand molar ratio was 1:1 and the resulting DMF or DMSO/water ratio was 2:3 v/v. The gel formed almost instantaneously. Gel formation was confirmed by the test tube inversion method. In a typical gelation experiment for CP2, 3-bpna (17 mg, 0.046 mmol) was dissolved in 0.4 mL of hot DMF to obtain a clear solution, and btc (9.7 mg, 0.046 mmol) was added; this solution was mixed with 0.6 mL of an aqueous solution of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (13.4 mg, 0.046 mmol) at room temperature so that the metal/3-bpna/btc molar ratio was 1:1:1 and the resulting DMF or DMSO/water ratio was 2:3 v/v. The gel formed almost instantaneously. Gel formation was confirmed by test tube inversion method.
elements.clean_text:
Metallogelation

In a typical gelation experiment for CP1, 3-bpna (22 mg, 0.06 mmol) was dissolved in 0.4 mL of hot DMF to obtain a clear solution and mixed with 0.6 mL of an aqueous solution of AgBF4 (11.7 mg, 0.06 mmol) at room temperature so that the metal/ligand molar ratio was 1:1 and the resulting DMF or DMSO/water ratio was 2:3 v/v. The gel formed almost instantaneously. Gel formation was confirmed by the test tube inversion method. In a typical gelation experiment for CP2, 3-bpna (17 mg, 0.046 mmol) was dissolved in 0.4 mL of hot DMF to obtain a clear solution, and btc (9.7 mg, 0.046 mmol) was added; this solution was mixed with 0.6 mL of an aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (13.4 mg, 0.046 mmol) at room temperature so that the metal/3-bpna/btc molar ratio was 1:1:1 and the resulting DMF or DMSO/water ratio was 2:3 v/v. The gel formed almost instantaneously. Gel formation was confirmed by test tube inversion method.

elements.content: TEM micrographs were recorded using a JEOL JEM-2011 instrument operating at 200 keV. Sample preparation involved drop casting a suspension of gel in water onto a 300 mesh carbon film supported by a copper grid, which was then dried in air.
elements.clean_text:
Transmission Electron Microscopy

TEM micrographs were recorded using a JEOL JEM-2011 instrument operating at 200 keV. Sample preparation involved drop casting a suspension of gel in water onto a 300 mesh carbon film supported by a copper grid, which was then dried in air.

elements.content: The rheological response of both metallogels was studied under dynamic and steady shear measurements at room temperature (25 °C) on parallel-plate geometry (25 mm diameter, 1 mm gap). Rheological experiments were carried out using an Anton Paar modular compact rheometer (MCR 102).
elements.clean_text:
Rheology Studies

The rheological response of both metallogels was studied under dynamic and steady shear measurements at room temperature (25 °C) on parallel-plate geometry (25 mm diameter, 1 mm gap). Rheological experiments were carried out using an Anton Paar modular compact rheometer (MCR 102).

elements.content: Suitable, apparently single crystals of 3-bpna and CP1–CP8 were selected. Data collection was carried out on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data reduction and unit cell refinement were performed using SAINT-Plus. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined using full-matrix least-squares based on F 2 values against all reflections, which was performed by SHELXL-2014/7.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction Analysis

Suitable, apparently single crystals of 3-bpna and CP1-CP8 were selected. Data collection was carried out on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data reduction and unit cell refinement were performed using SAINT-Plus. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined using full-matrix least-squares based on F 2 values against all reflections, which was performed by SHELXL-2014/7.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker AXS D8 Advance X-ray (Cu Kα1 radiation, λ = 1.5406 Å) diffractometer in the 5–35° 2θ range using a 0.02° step size per second. The sample was prepared by making a thin film from the finely powdered sample (∼30 mg) over a glass slide.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker AXS D8 Advance X-ray (Cu Kα1 radiation, λ = 1.5406 Å) diffractometer in the 5-35° 2θ range using a 0.02° step size per second. The sample was prepared by making a thin film from the finely powdered sample (~30 mg) over a glass slide.

elements.content: The acylamide ligand 3-bpna was synthesized by reacting 2,6-naphthalenedicarbonyl dichloride with 3-aminopyridine in a dichloromethane (DCM)/THF mixture under refluxing conditions. Blocked-shape crystals of 3-bpna were grown by slow evaporation from a DMSO solution. CP1 was crystallized by layering a CH3CN solution of AgBF4 onto a DMSO solution containing 3-bpna at room temperature for 3 weeks to afford X-ray quality blocked-shape crystals. Crystals for CP2–CP8 were obtained by solvothermal reaction in a DMF/methanol/water solution (3:1:1). We reacted 3-bpna (in separate experiments) with various polycarboxylates and several metal salts [AgBF4, Co­(NO3)2·6H2O, Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O, and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O] in a 1:1:1 (metal/3-bpna/polycarboxylate) molar ratio to generate CP2–CP8. Crystallographic data, bond length and bond angles, and hydrogen-bonding parameters for all of the crystals are listed in , S1, and S2, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The acylamide ligand 3-bpna was synthesized by reacting 2,6-naphthalenedicarbonyl dichloride with 3-aminopyridine in a dichloromethane (DCM)/THF mixture under refluxing conditions. Blocked-shape crystals of 3-bpna were grown by slow evaporation from a DMSO solution. CP1 was crystallized by layering a CH3CN solution of AgBF4 onto a DMSO solution containing 3-bpna at room temperature for 3 weeks to afford X-ray quality blocked-shape crystals. Crystals for CP2-CP8 were obtained by solvothermal reaction in a DMF/methanol/water solution (3:1:1). We reacted 3-bpna (in separate experiments) with various polycarboxylates and several metal salts [AgBF4, Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O, and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O] in a 1:1:1 (metal/3-bpna/polycarboxylate) molar ratio to generate CP2-CP8. Crystallographic data, bond length and bond angles, and hydrogen-bonding parameters for all of the crystals are listed in , S1, and S2, respectively.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 3-bpna crystallizes in the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit containing half of 3-bpna as the free ligand is located on a center of inversion. Both of the amide groups of 3-bpna are in an antiperiplanar conformation. The molecule is significantly nonplanar, as is evident from the dihedral angle of 13.2° involving the terminal pyridyl rings and the central naphthyl spacer. The N atoms of the terminal pyridyl rings are disposed in a trans conformation. In the crystal structure, the amide functionality is involved in hydrogen bonding via N–H···N interactions with the pyridyl N atoms of the neighboring molecules, resulting in herringbone packing when viewed down the c-axis ()
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of N',N"-Bis(3-pyridyl)naphthalene-2,6-dicarboxamide (3-bpna)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 3-bpna crystallizes in the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit containing half of 3-bpna as the free ligand is located on a center of inversion. Both of the amide groups of 3-bpna are in an antiperiplanar conformation. The molecule is significantly nonplanar, as is evident from the dihedral angle of 13.2° involving the terminal pyridyl rings and the central naphthyl spacer. The N atoms of the terminal pyridyl rings are disposed in a trans conformation. In the crystal structure, the amide functionality is involved in hydrogen bonding via N-H⋅⋅⋅N interactions with the pyridyl N atoms of the neighboring molecules, resulting in herringbone packing when viewed down the c-axis ()

elements.content: The crystal of CP1 belongs to the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit consists of half of AgI located on an inversion center, half of a 3-bpna molecule whose central naphthyl ring resides on an inversion center, half of a BF4 – anion (located on a 2-fold), and a fully occupied CH3CN molecule. The angle between the planes of the terminal pyridyl moieties and the central naphthyl spacer is 5.82°, indicating that 3-bpna ligand is reasonably planar. The metal center AgI displays a linear coordination geometry wherein the coordinating sites are occupied by the pyridyl N atoms of 3-bpna, forming a 1D CPic chain propagating approximately along the diagonal of the ab plane. One of the fluorine atoms (F2) of the BF4– anion is disordered and modeled over two positions. The >CO of the amide functionality is not involved in any intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interaction. However, the N–H of the amide is involved in hydrogen bonding with the BF4– anion that bridges adjacent 1D polymeric chains skewed at 52.8°, and such packing of the 1D chains results in a void space occupied by the lattice occluded solvent molecule CH3CN stabilized by a weak C–H···N hydrogen bond (Table S2). In addition, 3-bpna also experiences π···π interactions, with interplanar distances of 3.611 Å between the pyridyl and naphthyl rings ().
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [{Ag0.5(μ-3-bpna)}0.5⋅0.5BF4⋅CH3CN]α (CP1)

The crystal of CP1 belongs to the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit consists of half of AgI located on an inversion center, half of a 3-bpna molecule whose central naphthyl ring resides on an inversion center, half of a BF4 - anion (located on a 2-fold), and a fully occupied CH3CN molecule. The angle between the planes of the terminal pyridyl moieties and the central naphthyl spacer is 5.82°, indicating that 3-bpna ligand is reasonably planar. The metal center AgI displays a linear coordination geometry wherein the coordinating sites are occupied by the pyridyl N atoms of 3-bpna, forming a 1D CPic chain propagating approximately along the diagonal of the ab plane. One of the fluorine atoms (F2) of the BF4- anion is disordered and modeled over two positions. The >CO of the amide functionality is not involved in any intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interaction. However, the N-H of the amide is involved in hydrogen bonding with the BF4- anion that bridges adjacent 1D polymeric chains skewed at 52.8°, and such packing of the 1D chains results in a void space occupied by the lattice occluded solvent molecule CH3CN stabilized by a weak C-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bond (Table S2). In addition, 3-bpna also experiences π⋅⋅⋅π interactions, with interplanar distances of 3.611 Å between the pyridyl and naphthyl rings ().

elements.content: Crystal structure illustration of CP1: (a) ORTEP plot (30% probability level); (b) packing of 1D chains viewed down the a-axis (CH3CN is shown as a ball and stick model in pink and blue; AgI is shown as a green ball).

elements.content: CP2 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of two CoII metal centers (one fully occupied and the other half occupied, as it sits on a center of inversion), one btc, two 3-bpna ligands (one fully occupied and the other half occupied as the central naphthyl moiety sits on an inversion center), one coordinated aqua ligand, three lattice occluded DMF molecules, and three solvate water molecules. The ligand 3-bpna is significantly nonplanar, as is evident from the dihedral angles (50.8° and 58.9°) involving the terminal pyridyl rings and the central naphthyl moiety. Both of the metal centers display octahedral geometry; while the fully occupied CoII center displays slightly distorted octahedral geometry, the other one has a perfect octahedral geometry owing to its special position (center of inversion). The axial sites were coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms of ligand 3-bpna, and the equatorial positions are occupied by O atoms of the carboxylate and water molecules. The tricarboxylate co-ligand, namely, btc, coordinates through its carboxylate O atoms to CoII metal centers, resulting in a 2D sheets propagating parallel to the ac plane. The 2D sheets are further threaded by 3-bpna ligands via pyridyl N–Co coordination, resulting in an overall 3D network. The void spaces within the 3D network are occupied by the solvate DMF and water molecules, which are sustained by various hydrogen bonds of the type N–H···O and O–H···O. Topological analysis reveals that the network present in CP2 is a 3,4,6-connected net also known as sqc130 topology (). A similar 3,4,6-connected topology based on a cadmium phenylenediacetate isonicotinate CP has been reported recently.

Crystal Structure of [{(H2O)Co1.5(μ-3-bpna)1.5(μ-btc)}⋅3DMF⋅3H2O]α (CP2)

The asymmetric unit consists of two CoII metal centers (one fully occupied and the other half occupied, as it sits on a center of inversion), one btc, two 3-bpna ligands (one fully occupied and the other half occupied as the central naphthyl moiety sits on an inversion center), one coordinated aqua ligand, three lattice occluded DMF molecules, and three solvate water molecules. The ligand 3-bpna is significantly nonplanar, as is evident from the dihedral angles (50.8° and 58.9°) involving the terminal pyridyl rings and the central naphthyl moiety. Both of the metal centers display octahedral geometry; while the fully occupied CoII center displays slightly distorted octahedral geometry, the other one has a perfect octahedral geometry owing to its special position (center of inversion). The axial sites were coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms of ligand 3-bpna, and the equatorial positions are occupied by O atoms of the carboxylate and water molecules. The tricarboxylate co-ligand, namely, btc, coordinates through its carboxylate O atoms to CoII metal centers, resulting in a 2D sheets propagating parallel to the ac plane. The 2D sheets are further threaded by 3-bpna ligands via pyridyl N-Co coordination, resulting in an overall 3D network. The void spaces within the 3D network are occupied by the solvate DMF and water molecules, which are sustained by various hydrogen bonds of the type N-H⋅⋅⋅O and O-H⋅⋅⋅O. elements.content: CP3 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of one CdII, one hbtc2–, one 3-bpna, two lattice occluded water molecules, and one methanol. The ligand 3-bpna is nearly planar, as is evident from the dihedral angles involving the pyridyl moieties and the central naphthyl ring (12.45° and 17.82°). The CdII metal center displays distorted octahedral geometry wherein the equatorial positions are occupied by the carboxylate O atoms and the axial sites are coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms. The monoprotonated Hbtc2− is found to coordinate to the adjacent CdII metal centers, resulting in a 1D looped chain; such chains are further bridged by the bis-pyridyl ligand 3-bpna, resulting in an overall 2D coordination network. The 2D sheets are packed in parallel fashion, which are further sustained by intersheet N–H···O interactions involving the amide N–H and >CO of the COOH moiety of Hbtc2− and π···π stacking (3.793–3.922 Å, between the pyridyl···pyridyl, naphthyl···naphthyl, and naphthyl···pyridyl rings). The solvate CH3OH is hydrogen-bonded with the amide N–H and the carboxylate via N–H···O and O–H···O interactions, respectively. Two solvate water molecules are hydrogen-bonded with each other via O–H···O interactions; one of the water molecules further forms a hydrogen bond with the amide carbonyl and COOH of Hbtc2−. The overall network may best described as four-connected uninodal framework, as suggested by topological analysis ().

Crystal Structure of [{Cd(μ-3-bpna)(μ-hbtc)}⋅CH3OH⋅2H2O]α (CP3)

 CP3 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of one CdII, one hbtc2-, one 3-bpna, two lattice occluded water molecules, and one methanol. The ligand 3-bpna is nearly planar, as is evident from the dihedral angles involving the pyridyl moieties and the central naphthyl ring (12.45° and 17.82°). The CdII metal center displays distorted octahedral geometry wherein the equatorial positions are occupied by the carboxylate O atoms and the axial sites are coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms. The monoprotonated Hbtc2- is found to coordinate to the adjacent CdII metal centers, resulting in a 1D looped chain; such chains are further bridged by the bis-pyridyl ligand 3-bpna, resulting in an overall 2D coordination network. The 2D sheets are packed in parallel fashion, which are further sustained by intersheet N-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions involving the amide N-H and >CO of the COOH moiety of Hbtc2- and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking (3.793-3.922 Å, between the pyridyl⋅⋅⋅pyridyl, naphthyl⋅⋅⋅naphthyl, and naphthyl⋅⋅⋅pyridyl rings). The solvate CH3OH is hydrogen-bonded with the amide N-H and the carboxylate via N-H⋅⋅⋅O and O-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions, respectively. Two solvate water molecules are hydrogen-bonded with each other via O-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions; one of the water molecules further forms a hydrogen bond with the amide carbonyl and COOH of Hbtc2-. The overall network may best described as four-connected uninodal framework, as suggested by topological analysis ().

elements.content: CP4 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of one CoII, one isophthalate (ipa), one 3-bpna, two lattice occluded water molecules, and one unligated DMF. The ligand 3-bpna is significantly nonplanar, as is evident from the dihedral angles (39.7° and 44.8°) involving the terminal pyridyl rings and the central naphthyl moiety. The CoII metal center displays distorted octahedral geometry wherein the equatorial positions are occupied by the carboxylate O atoms and the axial sites are coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms.

The ligand 3-bpna is significantly nonplanar, as is evident from the dihedral angles (39.7° and 44.8°) involving the terminal pyridyl rings and the central naphthyl moiety. The CoII metal center displays distorted octahedral geometry wherein the equatorial positions are occupied by the carboxylate O atoms and the axial sites are coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms.

elements.content: CP5 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit consists of a CoII, one 1,3-pda, one 3-bpna molecule, and one occluded DMF molecule. The ligand 3-bpna significantly deviates from planarity, as is evident from the dihedral angles involving the pyridyl moieties and the central naphthyl ring (3.6° and 20.8°). The CoII metal center displays distorted octahedral geometry wherein the equatorial positions are occupied by the carboxylate O atoms and the axial sites are coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms. Remarkably, the dicarboxylate 1,3-pda ligand adopts cis conformations rather than a much more stable, and usually observed, trans conformation; 1,3-pda displays a tridentate bridging mode, with one carboxylate chelating (μ1-η1:η1) to one CoII and the other carboxylate bridging two CoII atoms, with each oxygen atom acting as a monodentate donor (μ2-η1:η1). Such a coordination mode results in a 1D looped chain topology that is further bridged by the bis-pyridyl ligand 3-bpna, producing an overall 2D coordination network. The 2D sheets are packed in parallel fashion. The interstitial space is occupied by the solvate DMF, which is sustained by N–H···O and C–H···π (Cg···H–C = 2.787 Å) interactions involving the amide N–H and DMF >CO and the DMF methyl and aromatic moiety of 1,3-pda, respectively. The overall network may best be described as a four-connected uninodal framework, as suggested by topological analysis ().
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [{Co(μ-3-bpna)(μ-1,3-pda)}⋅DMF]α (CP5)

 CP5 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit consists of a CoII, one 1,3-pda, one 3-bpna molecule, and one occluded DMF molecule. The ligand 3-bpna significantly deviates from planarity, as is evident from the dihedral angles involving the pyridyl moieties and the central naphthyl ring (3.6° and 20.8°). The CoII metal center displays distorted octahedral geometry wherein the equatorial positions are occupied by the carboxylate O atoms and the axial sites are coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms. Remarkably, the dicarboxylate 1,3-pda ligand adopts cis conformations rather than a much more stable, and usually observed, trans conformation; 1,3-pda displays a tridentate bridging mode, with one carboxylate chelating (μ1-η1:η1) to one CoII and the other carboxylate bridging two CoII atoms, with each oxygen atom acting as a monodentate donor (μ2-η1:η1). Such a coordination mode results in a 1D looped chain topology that is further bridged by the bis-pyridyl ligand 3-bpna, producing an overall 2D coordination network. The 2D sheets are packed in parallel fashion. The interstitial space is occupied by the solvate DMF, which is sustained by N-H⋅⋅⋅O and C-H⋅⋅⋅π (Cg⋅⋅⋅H-C = 2.787 Å) interactions involving the amide N-H and DMF >CO and the DMF methyl and aromatic moiety of 1,3-pda, respectively. The overall network may best be described as a four-connected uninodal framework, as suggested by topological analysis ().

elements.content: CP6 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit consists of a CdII, one 1,3-pda moiety, and half of a 3-bpna molecule (located on an inversion center). The ligand 3-bpna is nonplanar, as is evident from the dihedral angles involving the pyridyl moieties and the central naphthyl ring (20.9°). The CdII metal center displays distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry wherein the equatorial positions are occupied by the carboxylate O atoms and the axial sites are coordinated by the pyridyl N atom and one of the carboxylate O atoms. 1,3-pda displays the usually observed trans conformation (contrary to that observed in CP5) and is involved in a trans-tetradentate bridging mode, with one acetate arm chelating (μ1-η1:η1) to one CdII center and the other arm chelating as well as bridging (μ3-η2:η2) three CdII metal centers, resulting in a 2D network. The bis-pyridyl ligand 3-bpna bridges the 2D sheets packed in parallel fashion, resulting in an overall 3D network. The amide N–H is involved in hydrogen bonding with the carboxylate O via N–H···O interactions. The overall network may best be described as a five-connected uninodal new topology, as suggested by topological analysis ().
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Cd(μ-3-bpna)0.5(μ-1,3-pda)]α (CP6)

 CP6 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit consists of a CdII, one 1,3-pda moiety, and half of a 3-bpna molecule (located on an inversion center). The ligand 3-bpna is nonplanar, as is evident from the dihedral angles involving the pyridyl moieties and the central naphthyl ring (20.9°). The CdII metal center displays distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry wherein the equatorial positions are occupied by the carboxylate O atoms and the axial sites are coordinated by the pyridyl N atom and one of the carboxylate O atoms. 1,3-pda displays the usually observed trans conformation (contrary to that observed in CP5) and is involved in a trans-tetradentate bridging mode, with one acetate arm chelating (μ1-η1:η1) to one CdII center and the other arm chelating as well as bridging (μ3-η2:η2) three CdII metal centers, resulting in a 2D network. The bis-pyridyl ligand 3-bpna bridges the 2D sheets packed in parallel fashion, resulting in an overall 3D network. The amide N-H is involved in hydrogen bonding with the carboxylate O via N-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions. The overall network may best be described as a five-connected uninodal new topology, as suggested by topological analysis ().

elements.content: Crystal structure illustration of CP6: (a) ORTEP plot (50% probability level) and polyhedral view for the CdII coordination environment; (b) coordination modes of 1,3-pda; (c) 2D sheet; (d) topological representation of the 3D network found in CP6 (topological figures were drawn using X-Seed).
elements.clean_text: 7  Crystal structure illustration of CP6: (a) ORTEP plot (50% probability level) and polyhedral view for the CdII coordination environment; (b) coordination modes of 1,3-pda; (c) 2D sheet; (d) topological representation of the 3D network found in CP6 (topological figures were drawn using X-Seed).

elements.content: CP7 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of half of CoII, half of a 1,4-pda, and half of a 3-bpna ligand, all residing on an inversion center, and a fully occupied aqua ligand. The ligand 3-bpna is almost planar, as is evident from the dihedral angles involving the pyridyl moieties and the central naphthyl ring (3.7°). The CoII metal center displays perfect octahedral geometry owing to its special position (center of inversion) wherein the equatorial positions are occupied by the carboxylate O atoms and coordinated water molecules and the axial sites are coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms. 1,4-pda ligand bridges CoII atoms in a trans coordination fashion to form a 1D chain, which is further tethered by 3-bpna ligands to form a 2D corrugated (4,4) rhomboid network. Parallel corrugated 2D sheets stack in an interdigitating fashion, which is sustained by intersheet N–H···O interactions involving the amide N–H and carboxylate O and O–H···O interactions involving the metal bound water and carboxylate. The overall network may best be described as a four-connected uninodal network, as suggested by topological analysis ().
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [(H2O)Co0.5(μ-3-bpna)0.5(μ-1,4-pda)0.5]α (CP7)

 CP7 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of half of CoII, half of a 1,4-pda, and half of a 3-bpna ligand, all residing on an inversion center, and a fully occupied aqua ligand. The ligand 3-bpna is almost planar, as is evident from the dihedral angles involving the pyridyl moieties and the central naphthyl ring (3.7°). The CoII metal center displays perfect octahedral geometry owing to its special position (center of inversion) wherein the equatorial positions are occupied by the carboxylate O atoms and coordinated water molecules and the axial sites are coordinated by the pyridyl N atoms. 1,4-pda ligand bridges CoII atoms in a trans coordination fashion to form a 1D chain, which is further tethered by 3-bpna ligands to form a 2D corrugated (4,4) rhomboid network. Parallel corrugated 2D sheets stack in an interdigitating fashion, which is sustained by intersheet N-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions involving the amide N-H and carboxylate O and O-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions involving the metal bound water and carboxylate. The overall network may best be described as a four-connected uninodal network, as suggested by topological analysis ().

elements.content: Crystal structure illustration of CP7: (a) ORTEP plot (50% probability level); (b) packing 2D sheets; (c) topological representation of the 2D network found in CP7 (topological figures were drawn using X-Seed).
elements.clean_text: 8  Crystal structure illustration of CP7: (a) ORTEP plot (50% probability level); (b) packing 2D sheets; (c) topological representation of the 2D network found in CP7 (topological figures were drawn using X-Seed).

elements.content: CP8 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of a ZnII, one 4,4′-oxybis-benzoate (oba), one 3-bpna, two lattice occluded water molecules, and one DMF molecule. The ligand 3-bpna is nonplanar, as is evident from the dihedral angles involving the pyridyl moieties and the central naphthyl ring (61.57° and 35.57°). The ZnII metal center displays square pyramidal coordination geometry coordinated by carboxylate O atoms and the pyridyl N atoms. The flexible oba ligand bridges the neighboring ZnII metal center, resulting in a 1D chain that is further threaded by the bispyridyl ligand 3-bpna, producing a corrugated 2D sheet. The adjacent sheets are intercalated into a 3D layered architecture through strong aromatic π···π stacking interactions between 3-bpna ligands (Cg···Cg = 3.447 Å). Interestingly, the adjacent 2D sheets are arranged in ABAB... fashion. The interstitial space within the network is occupied by the solvate water and DMF molecules, which are sustained by hydrogen-bonding interactions; the water molecule is involved in hydrogen bonding with the amide N–H, and DMF takes part in hydrogen-bonding interactions with the water. The overall network may best described as a uninodal four-connected network, as suggested by topological analysis ().
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [{Zn(μ-3-bpna)(μ-oba)}⋅DMF⋅2H2O]α (CP8)

 CP8 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit consists of a ZnII, one 4,4'-oxybis-benzoate (oba), one 3-bpna, two lattice occluded water molecules, and one DMF molecule. The ligand 3-bpna is nonplanar, as is evident from the dihedral angles involving the pyridyl moieties and the central naphthyl ring (61.57° and 35.57°). The ZnII metal center displays square pyramidal coordination geometry coordinated by carboxylate O atoms and the pyridyl N atoms. The flexible oba ligand bridges the neighboring ZnII metal center, resulting in a 1D chain that is further threaded by the bispyridyl ligand 3-bpna, producing a corrugated 2D sheet. The adjacent sheets are intercalated into a 3D layered architecture through strong aromatic π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions between 3-bpna ligands (Cg⋅⋅⋅Cg = 3.447 Å). Interestingly, the adjacent 2D sheets are arranged in ABAB... fashion. The interstitial space within the network is occupied by the solvate water and DMF molecules, which are sustained by hydrogen-bonding interactions; the water molecule is involved in hydrogen bonding with the amide N-H, and DMF takes part in hydrogen-bonding interactions with the water. The overall network may best described as a uninodal four-connected network, as suggested by topological analysis ().

elements.content: The foregoing structural description of the free ligand and all of the CPs reveals the following (): The bispyridyl ligand displays trans ligating topology with respect to the terminal pyridyl moieties in all of the crystal structures of the CPs as well as the free ligand (Figure S1). The amide functionality is found to be antiperiplanar in all structures except for CP6 and CP8 (syn-periplanar). In most cases, the dihedral angle involving the terminal pyridyl rings and the central naphthyl moiety indicates a significant nonplanarity of the ligand 3-bpna. In the mixed ligand CPs, the carboxylate co-ligands display various coordination mode, including bidentate, tridentate, and tetradentate, depending on how the carboxylate O takes part in coordination. Except for CP6, the metal centers displays perfect to distorted octahedral geometry wherein the equatorial positions are mostly occupied by the carboxylate O atoms. Threading the pyridyl N atoms of 3-bpna ligand to the axial sites of the octahedral metal center leads mainly to a 2D coordination architecture except in CP2 and CP6; these two CPs display a 3D coordination network. The most important feature of the CPs reported herein, as envisaged, is that the majority of them have occluded solvent in their crystal lattice; only CP6 and CP7 did not occlude any solvent in the crystal structures. It should be noted that naphthyl-based bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands having similar structural features to 3-bpna also produced lattice occluded coordination polymers in mixed ligand systems.

The amide functionality is found to be antiperiplanar in all structures except for CP6 and CP8 (syn-periplanar). In most cases, the dihedral angle involving the terminal pyridyl rings and the central naphthyl moiety indicates a significant nonplanarity of the ligand 3-bpna. In the mixed ligand CPs, the carboxylate co-ligands display various coordination mode, including bidentate, tridentate, and tetradentate, depending on how the carboxylate O takes part in coordination. Except for CP6, the metal centers displays perfect to distorted octahedral geometry wherein the equatorial positions are mostly occupied by the carboxylate O atoms. Threading the pyridyl N atoms of 3-bpna ligand to the axial sites of the octahedral metal center leads mainly to a 2D coordination architecture except in CP2 and CP6; these two CPs display a 3D coordination network. The most important feature of the CPs reported herein, as envisaged, is that the majority of them have occluded solvent in their crystal lattice; only CP6 and CP7 did not occlude any solvent in the crystal structures. It should be noted that naphthyl-based bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligands having similar structural features to 3-bpna also produced lattice occluded coordination polymers in mixed ligand systems.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns are provided in the Supporting Information for 3-bpna and CP1–CP8 (Figure S2). Except for CP1, in all cases, the experimental patterns agree well with the simulated patterns, indicating the phase purity of the bulk material. The experimental PXRD pattern of CP1 does exhibit a few extra peaks, which may indicate the presence of a small crystalline impurity. The lattice occluded solvent content in the single-crystal structures of all of the CPs was further verified by TGA (Figures S3–S10, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns are provided in the Supporting Information for 3-bpna and CP1-CP8 (Figure S2). Except for CP1, in all cases, the experimental patterns agree well with the simulated patterns, indicating the phase purity of the bulk material. The experimental PXRD pattern of CP1 does exhibit a few extra peaks, which may indicate the presence of a small crystalline impurity. The lattice occluded solvent content in the single-crystal structures of all of the CPs was further verified by TGA (Figures S3-S10, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Since the ligand 3-bpna contains a naphthalene moiety, which is a known fluorophore, we studied the photophysical properties of the free ligand 3-bpna and a few selected CPs, namely, CP2, CP5, and CP3 in the solid state. The bis-pyridyl-bis-amide ligand 3-bpna displays a broad emission band centered around ca. 415 nm (excitation wavelength, λex = 330 nm), which can be ascribed to the intraligand or ligand–ligand π–π* or n–π* transitions. The emission spectrum of CP3 (excitation wavelength, λex = 300 nm) also appeared to be similar to that of the free ligand, displaying a broad emission band centered around ca. 435 nm. Since the photoluminescent d10 metal center CdII is quite far away (ca. 10 Å) from the fluorophore core of 3-bpna in the crystal structure of CP3, it understandably did not affect the overall fluorescence. On the other hand, the emission spectra of CP2 and CP5 (excitation wavelength, λex = 300 nm) appeared to have a sharp characteristic, displaying a peak centered around ca. 380 nm with satellite peaks at ca. 370 and 400 nm. It is clear that in these cases the d7 metal center CoII was unable to quench the luminescence because of its distance (ca. 10 Å) from the naphthyl moiety in the respective crystal structures of the CPs (Figure S11, Supporting Information).

Since the majority of the CPs turned out to be inclusion materials, as envisaged, we decided to scan all of the CPs for potential metallogelation. Before that, we scanned the ligand 3-bpna for gelation, as the amide functionality is reported to be a gel-producing moiety. However, 3-bpna turned out to be a nongelator when it was scanned with various solvents (both polar and nonpolar). Metallogelation scanning revealed that the majority of the CPs failed to produce metallogels with the target solvent system, DMF/water. Only CP1 and CP2 produced metallogels with DMF/water. The minimum gelator concentrations (MGCs) were found to be 3.4 and 4.0% for CP1 and CP2, respectively, when considering all of the reactants. In a typical experiment, a DMF solution of the ligand(s) was mixed with an aqueous solution of the metal salt at room temperature so that the metal/ligand molar ratio was 1:1 and the resulting DMF/water ratio was 2:3 v/v. The gel formed almost instantaneously, which was visually confirmed by a tube inversion test.
elements.clean_text:
Gelation Studies

Since the majority of the CPs turned out to be inclusion materials, as envisaged, we decided to scan all of the CPs for potential metallogelation. Before that, we scanned the ligand 3-bpna for gelation, as the amide functionality is reported to be a gel-producing moiety. However, 3-bpna turned out to be a nongelator when it was scanned with various solvents (both polar and nonpolar). Metallogelation scanning revealed that the majority of the CPs failed to produce metallogels with the target solvent system, DMF/water. Only CP1 and CP2 produced metallogels with DMF/water. The minimum gelator concentrations (MGCs) were found to be 3.4 and 4.0% for CP1 and CP2, respectively, when considering all of the reactants. In a typical experiment, a DMF solution of the ligand(s) was mixed with an aqueous solution of the metal salt at room temperature so that the metal/ligand molar ratio was 1:1 and the resulting DMF/water ratio was 2:3 v/v. The gel formed almost instantaneously, which was visually confirmed by a tube inversion test.

elements.content: The viscoelastic nature of the gels was further confirmed by rheology. The amplitude sweep experiments, wherein elastic modulus (G′) and viscous modulus (G″) were plotted against the strain applied, suggested that a strain of 0.1% was appropriate for the frequency sweep experiments. Both CP1 and CP2 metallogels displayed the expected behavior of viscoelastic materials like gels; in both cases, G′ was greater than G″ throughout the frequency range, particularly on the longer time scale, which is typical of viscoelastic materials like gels.

elements.content: The morphology of the gel fibers was studied by transition electron microscopy (TEM) (). The dried gels prepared by drop casting a suspension of gel in water on a TEM grid revealed the existence of a highly entangled network of 1D tape-type fibers. Understandably, these fibers, formed by spontaneous self-assembly involving the organic linkers and the metal centers, were capable of immobilizing the solvent molecules, resulting in metallogels.

The dried gels prepared by drop casting a suspension of gel in water on a TEM grid revealed the existence of a highly entangled network of 1D tape-type fibers. Understandably, these fibers, formed by spontaneous self-assembly involving the organic linkers and the metal centers, were capable of immobilizing the solvent molecules, resulting in metallogels.

elements.content: Since AgI is prone to photochemical reduction to produce Ag0 nanoparticles (hereafter, AgNP) under suitable conditions, the gel obtained from CP1 was exposed to sunlight for a day. It was observed that the color of the gel turned from white to brown, indicating AgNP formation. The tiny particles (3–10 nm) seen in the TEM image of the dried gel of CP1 presumably were AgNPs. Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) performed using the transmission electron microscope revealed that these particles were crystalline, as they produced well-ordered diffraction spots. The existence of AgNPs was finally confirmed by the surface plasmon resonance peak at ∼470 nm in the UV–vis spectrum of the suspended xerogel of CP1 in DMSO. The formation of metal nanoparticles, including AgNPs, within a gel bed has been previously reported by us and others.

elements.content: Attempts to gain insight into the gel network’s structure by powder X-ray diffraction were not successful because both of the CPs evaluated (CP1 and CP2) are lattice occluded molecular solids that are susceptible to desolvation, leading to changes in and/or collapse of the crystal lattice. Moreover, in the case CP1, Ag nanoparticles were formed, indicating partial degradation of the coordination network, which led to different PXRD patterns (Figure S12).

elements.content: A new, hitherto unexplored, flexible ligand equipped with hydrogen-bonding functionality (amide), namely, 3-bpna, was explored to obtain access to a new series of coordination polymers by reacting it with various metal salts and carboxylate coligands. As envisaged, the majority of the coordination polymers turned out to be lattice occluded molecular solids; various hydrogen-bonding-capable solvent molecules (DMF/water/MeOH/MeCN) were found to be occluded within the interstitial space of the coordination networks, which were sustained by hydrogen bonding with the amide functionality and/or metal bound water molecules. Contrary to our expectation, reactions of the CPs, in the majority of cases, failed to produce a metallogel with DMF/water or DMSO/water; only in the cases of CP1 and CP2 were the expected metallogels formed. Ultimately, a gel is formed only when the gel network is able to immobilize the target solvent via capillary force action or surface tension that solely depends on the surface compatibility between the gel network and the solvent molecules. Thus, the presence of gel network characteristics in the structure of a gelator molecule does not necessarily ensure gelation. The reason that the other CPs (CP3–CP8) were nongelator must be because of surface incompatibility of the network structure and the target solvent molecules. These results clearly indicate that much understanding is still needed at the molecular level to be able to design metallogelators a priori. Nevertheless, the logical approach adopted herein to obtain access to metallogels was worthwhile.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A new, hitherto unexplored, flexible ligand equipped with hydrogen-bonding functionality (amide), namely, 3-bpna, was explored to obtain access to a new series of coordination polymers by reacting it with various metal salts and carboxylate coligands. As envisaged, the majority of the coordination polymers turned out to be lattice occluded molecular solids; various hydrogen-bonding-capable solvent molecules (DMF/water/MeOH/MeCN) were found to be occluded within the interstitial space of the coordination networks, which were sustained by hydrogen bonding with the amide functionality and/or metal bound water molecules. Contrary to our expectation, reactions of the CPs, in the majority of cases, failed to produce a metallogel with DMF/water or DMSO/water; only in the cases of CP1 and CP2 were the expected metallogels formed. Ultimately, a gel is formed only when the gel network is able to immobilize the target solvent via capillary force action or surface tension that solely depends on the surface compatibility between the gel network and the solvent molecules. Thus, the presence of gel network characteristics in the structure of a gelator molecule does not necessarily ensure gelation. The reason that the other CPs (CP3-CP8) were nongelator must be because of surface incompatibility of the network structure and the target solvent molecules. These results clearly indicate that much understanding is still needed at the molecular level to be able to design metallogelators a priori. Nevertheless, the logical approach adopted herein to obtain access to metallogels was worthwhile.

To a solution of 2,6-napthalenedicarboxylic acid (500 mg, 2.3 mmol) in dry dichloromethane (DCM) were added 2 mL of oxalyl chloride and 4 drops of DMF, and the mixture was stirred with a gut tube for 12 h to yield a yellow suspension that was dried under vacuum. The dried powder was stirred in toluene for 2 h, and the sticky mass of oxalyl chloride was removed by decanting the toluene solution, which was further evaporated to isolate the pure acid chloride as a dried mass (600 mg, 2.37 mmol, yield: 70%).

To a solution of the acid chloride (550 mg, 2.1 mmol) and 1 mL of triethylamine in dry DCM was added 3-amino pyridine (395 mg, 4.2 mmol) in dry THF dropwise. The thick white colored precipitate thus formed was stirred with refluxing for 12 h. After filtration, the precipitate was washed with a DCM/THF mixture, air-dried, treated with a 5% NaHCO3 solution, washed with distilled water, dried, and recrystallized from DMSO (yield: 650 mg, 70%). The synthetic procedure was similar to that of CP2 under solvothermal conditions from a DMF/methanol/water solution of a mixture of 3-bpna (30 mg, 0.08 mmol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (23.2 mg, 0.08 mmol), and 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (15.52 mg, 0.08 mmol). After cooling, block-shaped pink crystals were isolated. Anal. Calcd for C32H26CoN4O6 (%): C, 60.02; H, 4.22; N, 9.01 Found: C, 59.31; H, 4.62; N, 8.62. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3321, 3028, 1670, 1606, 1539, 1487, 1390, 1338, 1303, 1257, 1182, 1134, 894, 813, 790, 757, 703, 624, 599, 584.

CP8

The synthetic procedure was similar to that of CP2 under solvothermal conditions from a DMF/methanol/water solution of a mixture of 3-bpna (30 mg, 0.08 mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (24.6 mg, 0.08 mmol), and oxy-bisbenzoic acid (20.6 mg, 0.08 mmol). After cooling, plate-shaped crystals were isolated. Anal. Calcd for C44H46ZnN4O10 (%): C, 61.72; H, 4.68; N, 9.13. Found: C, 61.01; H, 4.08; N, 8.63. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3276, 3078, 1666, 1595, 1544, 1500, 1421, 1400, 1284, 1232, 1188, 1134, 877, 808, 784, 773, 698, 663, 649, 599.
